page.title: 01COAST WEST OF LOSSIE MOUTH
page.content: The block is largely composed of sea, this being a section of the southern shore of the Moray Firth. This particular stretch of coastline is made up of gentle cliffs, topped with rough heathland, coves and caves. One cave contains wall paintings, believed to be pictish. The local sandstone is quarried along this stretch and has been variously used for millstones and building material. None of the coves on the stretch is suitable for use as a harbour, although there are several along the firth with active fishing fleets. There is a coastguard lookout here manned by boys from nearby Gordonstown School.
